title: You think you're invisible?
intro: Do you secretly watch people when in public? And do you think they're watching you? Neil and Dan explore some fascinating research about 'people-watching' and teach you six items of useful vocabulary in this episode of 6 Minute English.
this_week_question: OK, question time. Which of these stories features an invisibility cloak ?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: a long piece of material worn over the shoulders like a coat
something which appears real but isn't
difference between two things; a bad combination
too aware of yourself; embarrassed what others think about you

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Welcome to 6 Minute English, the programme where we explore an interesting topic and bring you six items of useful vocabulary. I'm Neil.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And I'm Dan.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, Dan, have you ever wanted to become invisible ?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Invisible – impossible to see. Of course! Who hasn't?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well how about this: most of us think we are in fact invisible, at least some of the time… We'll be looking at the ' invisibility cloak illusion ' in this programme.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Fascinating. And in that phrase we heard our first three words. Invisibility – the state of being invisible . A cloak is a long piece of material worn like a coat around the shoulders.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And the third word in that phrase – an illusion – is something that seems real but isn't.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: OK, question time. Which of these stories features an invisibility cloak ? Is it…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I know they are all connected to invisibility, but I'm gonna say…a) The Hobbit.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Ok – we'll reveal the answer later on. Now, let's hear more about this invisibility cloak illusion . What's the theory, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right – imagine you're sitting in a crowded train. People are busy looking at phones and books, but they're also looking at each other.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: They're 'people-watching', as we call it. Yes. Yes, I do that. I do it a lot, if I'm honest!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So – where does the invisibility part come in?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A team of scientists from Yale University did some experiments on this. Commenting on the research here is neuroscientist Dr Catherine Loveday from Westminster University. What did the Yale team find?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Catherine Loveday, Neuroscientist, Westminster University

transcript.author: mismatch
transcript.text: So this study, they asked people that, first they did a survey and they asked people sat in a canteen how much they were watching somebody, and how much they thought those people were observing them. And there was always a  . People always thought they were more observational than the people who were watching them.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: So, people think they observe others more than others watch them. Everyone thinks they aren't observed very much - it's almost as if they're invisible to others – or wearing an invisibility cloak !

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And the difference between how much they are actually being watched and think they're being watched is what she called a mismatch . It's the difference between two things – they're two things which don't 'match'.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: In other words – it's not true that people aren't watching us – which is why the idea of having an invisibility cloak is just an illusion . This next bit is interesting. Two people were asked to wait in a room. Then they were each asked to make two lists: one, what they noticed about the other person; and two, what they thought the other person noticed about them.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So list one was always longer than list two. Not only that – but there was also an important difference in the content of the lists.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Let's hear again from neuroscientist Dr Catherine Loveday. What was the difference?

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Dr Catherine Loveday, Neuroscientist, Westminster University When people are observing you they're doing it in a non- judgemental , fairly empathic way – and not actually noticing the things that you're self-conscious about. So if for example you feel self-conscious about a spot on your nose, or something that you're wearing, that won't be what they're noticing. It's a much less judgemental form of observation.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Right, so even if we're feeling self-conscious about something – that means feeling extra aware of an aspect of ourselves – maybe our appearance or our clothes – we needn't be.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes, you don't need to feel self-conscious . People aren't being judgemental .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And being judgemental means being critical.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: That's good news. So even though all I'm thinking about is how badly I need a haircut, the other person is probably noticing something completely different. Back to the question about the invisibility cloak . Which story is it in?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I said The Hobbit.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And it was in fact – Harry Potter. Not only does the garment make you impossible to see, it also protects you against magic spells.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Wow – I need one of those!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: In The Hobbit, it's a ring that makes you invisible , and in The Invisible Man, the main character uses chemicals to achieve the same effect.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Now, before we become invisible ourselves, how about we go through today's words?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Marvellous. First we had invisible – which meansimpossible to see. You could say that stars are invisible during the day.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: They're only visible at night.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We also had cloak – who would wear a cloak? Maybe a king or a monk? Or maybe you, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I'm sure I could look good in a cloak – that's a long piece of material worn over the shoulders. What about illusion ?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Illusions appear to be true, but they're not. It can describe an idea: you could say a politician has the illusion that everything he says is true. Then we had mismatch – which can refer to the difference between two things which perhaps should be similar: there's a mismatch between what Michael says and what he does.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Who's Michael?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Just an example! You could also say that Michael and Simone are an unlikely couple – they seem very different – they're a bit of a mismatch .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: What is it with you and Michael?! One, he doesn't exist, and two, I think you're being judgemental .

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, I'm criticising him so, yeah, you're right – I'm being judgemental . Perhaps I should stop. It's just that… it's just that I'm in love with Simone myself, and I get all nervous and self-conscious when I see her.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: You mean you become embarrassed about what she might think of you – you become self-conscious ?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I do.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Even though she doesn't exist either?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, only in my examples. Sometimes I wish I really did have an invisibility cloak .

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Hey, hang on, Dan - where have you gone?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Haha – very funny, I'm still perfectly visible. Time to go – but do visit our Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube pages, and of course our website!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Goodbye for now.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
